newsitem.title: USA: Former Reynolds researcher testifies at Fla. trial.
newsitem.headline: Former Reynolds researcher testifies at Fla. trial.

text.p: A former R.J. Reynolds Tobacco Co research biochemist testified Friday that the company shut down a research project in 1970 when it was making advances in determining whether smoking caused illness.

Joseph Bumgarner, who worked in the company's Biological Research Division from 1967 to 1970, testified about Reynolds' so-called "mouse house" experiments in which rats and rabbits were subjected to cigarette smoke to determine its effects on their health.
His testimony came on the 10th day of the trial of a wrongful death suit filed against Reynolds by Dana Raulerson, whose sister Jean Connor died of lung cancer at age 49.
Reynolds is a unit of RJR Nabisco Holdings Corp.

Bumgarner, 57, told jurors the experiments, some of which involved rabbits inhaling smoke through a tube directly into the their throats, appeared to be making progress in determining the possible health effects of cigarette smoking.
"We were very excited about what we were doing," he said. "I thought we made some pretty good advances.
Without warning, Bumgarner said, the researchers working on the project were called into a conference room in March 1970 and told the project was being shut down.
"We were told that the biological research division was being dissolved," he said.
He said the researchers were told to turn in their laboratory notebooks, which he believed had been destroyed until he learned in 1992 that a Reynolds' lawyer had copies of them.

The testimony appeared to advance a theme presented by Raulerson's lawyers to jurors throughout the widely watched trial -- that Reynolds knew smoking was dangerous but hid that knowledge from the public.
The plaintiffs have claimed that the company had a duty to know the dangers of their product and a responsibility to continue research to figure out health risks.
Bumgarner testified that a Reynolds veterinary pathologist had shown him slides that indicated emphysema was present in the tissue of several rabbits used in the experiment.

On cross-examination, Reynolds attorney Paul Crist displayed a confidential 1969 company memo that indicated three rabbits had died of emphysema but that it was probably because of bronchial pneumonia.
Bumgarner said he disagreed with that finding.
Asked whether the cigarette company should have published its research, Bumgarner said: "With more work, yes, the project should have been published."

Outside the courtroom, Bumgarner, who was testifying for the first time in a tobacco trial, said he believed the laboratory was shut down because researchers were coming up with test results that linked smoking to illness.
"There's not a doubt in my mind," he said. "I think what we were doing was making the (Reynolds) legal department very, very nervous."
Bumgarner, who now works for the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, said he smoked Salem brand cigarettes until about 12 years ago, when he quit after having a heart attack.
